_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 O'Neill Vintners & Distillers, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 - Main Processing          Anhydrous Ammonia                27,000

P2 - 900 Farm                 Anhydrous Ammonia                15,000

P4 - Sulfur Dioxide           Sulfur Dioxide                    8,000

P5 - Remote 900               Anhydrous Ammonia                12,500

P7 - Aqueous Ammonia          Aqueous Ammonia                  65,000



Note: Process 3 (Trailer Package) was decommissioned in 2016 with the installation of Process 5. Process 5 was designed by Axiom Engineers and installed by Cold Storage Technologies. Process 6 (Ethano

l) is only subject to OHSA's PSM regulations and managed separately. See Ethanol PSM Program.

 

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. 



Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



1.2.1 Facility Overview



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers operates a processing facility for wine and other alcoholic beverages in Parlier, CA. 



1.2.1.1 Process 1, 2, and 5 - Anhydrous Ammonia



The facility has three ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1 - Main Processing

(9) Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers

(3) Plate Heat Exchangers



Process 2 - 900 Tank Farm

(2) Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers



Process 5 - Remote 900

(3) Shell & Tube Heat Exchangers

(1) Plate Heat Exchanger



Note: Process 3 (Trailer Package) was decommissioned in 2016 with the installation of Process 5. 



1.2.1.2 Process 4 - Sulfur Dioxide



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has one (1) sulfur-dioxide process, which is used as a preservative to extend the life of wine produced. The sulfur-dioxide process consists of four (4) one-ton containers.



1.2.1.3 Process 7 - Aqueous Ammonia



The aqueous ammonia process at O'Neill Vintne

rs & Distillers involves the storage and transfer of 30% aqueous ammonia to the EQ (equalizer) tank for the purpose of adjusting the pH of effluent water.



1.2.2 Facility Location



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers is located at 8418 S Lac Jac Ave., Parlier, CA 93648. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver for Process 1 is 36.612299, -119.482976. The facility is located approximately 7.5 miles northeast of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agricultural land.



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has a <1% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Processes



1.2.3.1 Anhydrous Ammonia



The refrigerated areas are equipped with shell & tube or plate & frame heat exchangers and accumulators as required for flooded operation.

A partial list of system components includes: 



Process 1

(1) High pressure receiver

(2) Surge Drums

(4) Oil Pots

(3) Plate and frame heat exchangers

(9) Shell and tube heat exchangers with associated accumulators

(1) Plate and frame oil cooler

(4) Shell and tube oil cooler

(1) Main suction accumulator

(5) Screw compressors

(5) Oil separators

(3) Condensers

(1) Thermosyphon vessel

(1) Ammonia Diffusion Tank



Process 2

(1) High pressure receiver

(2) Shell and tube heat exchangers with associated accumulators

(1) Main suction accumulator

(3) Screw compressors

(3) Oil separators

(2) Condensers

(1) Ammonia Diffusion Tank



Process 5

(1) High pressure receiver

(3) Shell and tube heat exchangers

(2) Accumul

ed to the suction inlet on the screw compressors. The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within each condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. This system is also equipped with a thermosyphon vessel located between the evaporative condensers and high pressure receiver. The thermosyphon vessel supplies the screw compressor oil coolers with small amounts of high pressure liquid. As this liquid absorbs the heat from the oil, it evaporates inside the oil cooler, and returns to the thermosyphon vessel.



In Process 2, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to the suction accumulator. The liquid enters spiral piping inside the suction accumulator and is subcooled by the low pressure vapor/liquid inside the vessel. Simultaneously, the high pressure liquid transfers heat to liquid accumulated at the bottom of the vessel which evaporates to form low pressure vapor. Once the high pressure liquid exits the suction accumulator, it is piped to two (2) shell and tube heat exchangers. Each heat exchanger is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the heat exchanger. Inside the shell and tube heat exchangers, the low temperature liquid sits in the shell of the heat exchanger where it surrounds a bundle of tubes containing the medium being cooled. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temp

ators

(3) Oil Pots

(1) Plate and frame heat exchanger

(1) Main suction accumulator

(2) Screw compressors

(1) Reciprocating compressor

(1) Condensers

(1) Ammonia Diffusion Tank

(1) Thermosyphon vessel



Process Chemistry

The refrigeration systems employed at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers are flooded systems.



In Process 1, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to the suction accumulator. The liquid enters spiral piping inside the suction accumulator and is subcooled by the low pressure vapor/liquid inside the vessel. Simultaneously, the high pressure liquid transfers heat to liquid accumulated at the bottom of the vessel which evaporates to form low pressure vapor. Once the high pressure liquid exits the suction accumulator, it is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator supplies either one (1) shell and tube heat exchanger, one (1) plate and frame heat exchanger, or two (2) plate and frame heat exchangers with low temperature liquid. 



Inside the shell and tube heat exchangers, the low temperature liquid sits in the shell of the heat exchanger where it surrounds a bundle of tubes containing the medium being cooled. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which returns to the supplying accumulator. Inside the plate and frame heat exchangers, the low temperature liquid flows through channels in the plates and absorbs heat from the medium being cooled on the opposite side of each plate. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which returns to the supplying accumulator. 



From each of the accumulators, the low temperature vapor is piped to the suction accumulator where any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel. From the suction accumulator, the low pressure vapor is pip

erature gas which is piped to the suction accumulator. 



Inside the suction accumulator, any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and the low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors. The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within each condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. 



In Process 5, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to three (3) shell and tube heat exchangers and the suction accumulator. Each vessel or heat exchanger is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters each vessel or heat exchanger. 



Inside the shell and tube heat exchangers, the low temperature liquid sits in the shell of the heat exchanger where it surrounds a bundle of tubes containing the medium being cooled. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which is piped to the suction accumulator. Inside the plate and frame heat exchanger, the low temperature liquid flows through channels in the plates and absorbs heat from the water/glycol mixture on the opposite side of each plate. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which returns to the suction accumulator. The suction accumulator supplies low temperature liquid to a plate and frame heat exchanger. Inside the plate and frame heat exchanger, the lo

w temperature liquid flows through channels in the plates and absorbs heat from the water/glycol mixture on the opposite side of each plate. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which returns to the suction accumulator. 



From the suction accumulator, the low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw and reciprocating compressors. The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within each condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. This system is also equipped with a thermosyphon vessel located between the evaporative condensers and high pressure receiver. The thermosyphon vessel supplies the screw compressor oil coolers with small amounts of high pressure liquid. As this liquid absorbs the heat from the oil, it evaporates inside the oil cooler, and returns to the thermosyphon vessel.



Each ammonia refrigeration system at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers are treated as three (3) independent processes. 

 

1.2.3.2 Sulfur Dioxide



Process Chemistry



At O'Neill Vintners and Distillers sulfur dioxide is used as a preservative to extend the life of wine produced.



The addition process happens when the sulfur dioxide is injected into fre

shly extracted grape juice from the crush equipment or injected directly into the wine tanks as the product circulates through a pump. The treated juice is then piped to other processes in the facility or back into the wine tank.  Once the gas has been absorbed by the juice, it is no longer a hazard.



The sulfur dioxide ton containers are equipped with a sprinkler system to extinguish any fires near the containers and to mitigate the effects of a release of sulfur dioxide. The sprinkler system can be activated using the pull cord located on the south side of the fencing near the sulfur dioxide storage area.



Emergency Shutdown Cords



The sulfur dioxide system is equipped with three emergency shutoff cords: one is normally attached to the ton containers and the other two are attached to the shutoff valves directly upstream of each sulfur dioxide site glass for the crushers. These emergency shutoff cords can be used to shutoff the supply of sulfur dioxide to the crusher area in the event of an emergency.



1.2.3.3 Aqueous Ammonia



Process Chemistry



The aqueous ammonia process at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers involves the storage and transfer of 30% aqueous ammonia to the EQ (equalizer) tank for the purpose of adjusting the pH of effluent water. When ammonia is dissolved in water the theoretical reaction is as follows:



NH3 + H2O → NH4OH



However, it is known that dissociation takes place:



NH4OH → NH4+ + OH



Ammonia is considered a weak base and ionizes in water much less completely than a strong base such as sodium hydroxide. A molar solution of ammonia has a hydroxyl ion concentration of about 2 percent of that in a molar sodium hydroxide solution. 



Hydroxyl ion (and hydrogen ion) concentration is measured by pH. The pH scale is a series of numbers (0-14) expressing the degree of acidity or alkalinity of a solution, as compared to some reference solution. The inventor of the term pH was named Sorensen and he defined it as:



pH =

-log [H+] (negative log of hydrogen ion concentration)



A solution is neutral when all of the hydrogen ions are matched with hydroxide ions. At 25?C a neutral solution has a pH of 7.0. Aqueous ammonia solutions at the concentration levels of interest for typical situations will be in the pH range between 7 and 12. This part of the pH range is typically classified as weakly alkaline.



As ammonia is dissolved in water the pH elevates rapidly and then flattens out in the pH = 12 range. At 25?C the theoretical pH values for aqueous ammonia solutions of varying concentration are as follows:



1.2.4 Process Classification



Each individual process at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers consists of vessels, equipment, and/or valves which are interconnected by piping. The processes are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the systems at O'Neill Vintners & Distillers are treated as six (6) independent processes; three Anhydrous Ammonia refrigeration processes (P1, P2, and P5), one Sulfur Dioxide process (P4), one Ethanol process (P6), and one Aqueous Ammonia process (P7).



Note: Process 3 (Trailer Package) was decommissioned in 2016 with the installation of Process 5.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of each covered chemical in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for each process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the O'Neill Vintners & Distillers facility i

s an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 54,500 lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.3.3 Sulfur-Dioxide



The sulfur-dioxide process at the O'Neill Vintners & Distillers facility is an integral part of overall business and lasts for approximately five months out of the year. The sulfur-dioxide process contains multiple cylinders with a maximum inventory of 8,000 lbs. It is extremely important that these areas and associated injection processes are maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. O'Neill Vintners & Distillers is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of exposure to sulfur-dioxide.



Our personnel also monitor the sulfur-dioxide fumigation process and keep an active log of all associated procedures and transactions. In addition, the process is checked frequently during the season by the outside contractor that supplies the SO2 cylinders. The contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our process equipment. 



1.3.4 Aqueous Ammonia



The aqueous ammonia process at the O'Neill Vintners & Distillers facility is an integral part of overall business and operates most of the year. The aqueous ammonia process contains a storage tank  with a maximum inventory of 65,000 lbs of 30% aqueous ammonia.  It is extremely import

ant that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. O'Neill Vintners & Distillers is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of exposure to aqueous ammonia.



Our personnel also monitor the aqueous ammonia process and keep an active log of all associated procedures and transactions. In addition, the process is checked frequently during the season by the outside contractor that supplies the aqueous ammonia. The contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our process equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

O'Neill Vintners & Distillers' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved O'Neill Vintners & Distillers' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that O'Neill Vint

ners & Distillers' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, O'Neill Vintners & Distillers now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for O'Neill Vintners & Distillers employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program O'Neill Vintners & Distillers will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
